name: Use table-per-class-hierarchy when subclasses have few properties
description:
Reports all persistent (Hibernate & JPA) entities that don't use table-per-class-hierarchy strategy  for its subclasses when the maximum added attributes of subclasses don't exceed 3. This number is a thresholds that can be changed as will.
This verification is limited to the first level of entities inheritance tree. For example, if the entity inheritance tree contains an entity C that inherit from entity B, that inherit from entity A. only the number of fields of entity B will be analyzed, not those from entity C.
output:
List all Hibernate and/or JPA Entities that don't use table-per-class-hierarchy strategy for its subclasses when the maximum added attributes of subclasses don't exceed the threshold parameter.

It provides the following information:
 Hibernate and/or JPA Entity Full Name
rationale: If you require polymorphic associations (an association to a superclass, hence to all classes in the hierarchy with dynamic resolution of the concrete class at runtime) or queries, and sub-classes declare relatively few properties (particularly if the main difference between subclasses is in their behavior), lean toward the table-per-class-hierarchy model.
remediation: Use the table-per-class-hierarchy strategy to map the hierarchy.
remediationSample:
<class name="Animal" table="ANIMAL">
    <id name="id" type="long" column="ANIMAL_ID">
        <generator class="native"/>
    </id>
    <discriminator column="TYPE" type="string"/>
    <property name="amount" column="AMOUNT"/>

    // FIXED: table-per-class-hierarchy strategy is used
    <subclass name="Dog" discriminator-value="DOG">
        <property name="race" column="RACE"/>
    </subclass>

    <subclass name="Cat" discriminator-value="CAT">
        <property name="color" column="COLOR"/>
    </subclass>
</class>
sample:
----> animal.hbm.xml

<class name="Animal" table="ANIMAL">
    <id name="id" type="long" column="ANIMAL_ID">
        <generator class="native"/>
    </id>

    <property name="amount" column="AMOUNT"/>

     // VIOLATION none of the subclass attributes count 
     // is greater or equal to 3 and 
     // table-per-class-hierarchy strategy is not used

    <joined-subclass name="Dog" table="DOG">
        <key column="DOG_ID"/>
        <property name="race" column="RACE"/>
    </joined-subclass>

    <joined-subclass name="Cat" table="CAT">
        <key column="CAT_ID"/>
        <property name="color" column="COLOR"/>
    </joined-subclass>
</class>
total: Number of hibernate and/or JPA entities that are subclassed (subclass or joined-subclass) and that are not inheriting from another entity
alternativeName: ensure to use table-per-class-hierarchy when subclasses have few properties

technicalCriteria.name: Efficiency - SQL and Data Handling Performance
